comments.body: @doncat and his team are testing this on staging now. Hopefully we should hear back soon.

This isn't what we asked for.  Our "dream" was to be able to provide a text file of barcodes and sizes, for processing.  Entering barcodes one by one in a form and selecting a size for each one is pretty dysfunctional.  It's not impossible, but not what we would choose.  Isn't there a way to get the same barcode/size input for your process via uploading a text file?
Alternately, redesign so that the operator can declare or select a size and then sequentially scan barcodes for that size. When finished with it, select the next size and scan.  (Our end-processing shelves are size-sorted.)  If barcodes are duplicated in a batch, take the last one and its size.  That's what we are planning to do separately to make that text file we want to upload.  If something like that could be provided it would fit our conditions better.

> Isn't there a way to get the same barcode/size input for your process via uploading a text file?

Yeah, it's possible. The thing I'm concerned about is that a text file inherently has no sets of checks for if a prefix is valid and doesn't have a clear way to fix things. Further, it means changing your workflow is disconnected from changing the application and will inevitably lead to silent workarounds or cases where we have to parse if the file is okay or not.

> Alternately, redesign so that the operator can declare or select a size and then sequentially scan barcodes for that size. When finished with it, select the next size and scan. (Our end-processing shelves are size-sorted.) If barcodes are duplicated in a batch, take the last one and its size.

This is great! I can look into making the form respond with the assumption that items are often of the same size.

> If barcodes are duplicated in a batch, take the last one and its size.

@doncat One more thing - what in the workflow leads to barcodes being duplicated?

Text file is produced via Macro Express.  Easy as anything.  Size values are controlled.  Barcodes are checked for "32101" and length=14.   Everything is done via little forms.   We are used to this.  That's why I was able to describe it so clearly.
Barcodes are duplicated, maybe, because the operator forgot to change the size code.  Or, the cataloger put it on the wrong shelf.  Human beings.  It happened in old AbID too.  So, assuming the last is the right one.  The text file macro makes this barcode duplication check at some point and retains only the last one for further processing.
We intended to provide a clean text file to serve as input, created with minimal task load on the operator.  Looking forward to the in-app equivalent.

@doncat The "size-first" workflow is up on the staging site and a demo video is here:

https://vimeo.com/595547158
Another example: https://catalog.princeton.edu/catalog/9975711613506421

The problem is that bibdata is raising error "Multiple items found under the same key" from this part of the code: https://github.com/pulibrary/bibdata/blob/main/app/adapters/alma_adapter/availability_status.rb#L25-L39 for these records.

I took a quick look at the data that comes from Alma for one of the offending records (mms id: `99125379706706421`) and it has two holdings and each holding with two items. It is strange that the holding information for one of the holdings (`22897390520006421`) is different depending on where it comes in the response, in one instance it has information about a temp location for reserves whereas in the other it does not...for the exact same holding.

More to come.

The culprit is that we return the availability information grouped by `mms_id` + `holding_id` and in this case there are **multiple items** for the same the `mms_id` + `holding_id` combination. In hindsight this is an expected scenario but the code explicitly throws and exception when it happens because we had not decided what to do in this case (e.g. what is the availability of holding X if item X1 is available but item X2 is unavailable).

Another thing in common for these bib records is that all of them have at least one holding marked as a temporary location. That's really what forces bib data to try to calculate availability from the items (rather than using the data from the holding) and while aggregating the data from the items it bumps into the problem described in the previous paragraph.

I'll submit a PR with some ideas.

oawaiver.title: Increase the replicas for the staging and production Solr Collections

comments.body:
Record `99101494203506421` (Zhonghua jing dian gu ji ku) has no AVA/AVE data from Alma but there is one `856` which is why it shows Available Online in the Show page, but evidently we are not taking this into account in the Search page and therefore it shows "No holdings available for this record" in the Search results.

On the other hand, record `99125378800006421` (Liang jing xin ji ji jiao) has information in the AVA/AVE fields from Alma and also it has two `856` fields. The search results for this record displays Online, very likely because it picks up the information from the AVA/AVE fields.

orangelight.title: Record page - Control Digital Lending Items have status Unavailable
Availability display in Show page for CDL items

comments.body:
In the past we displayed for cdl item status: 'Reserved for digital lending'.  https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/blob/a1a88135b5331b30b087d97263c32da2fba208ac/app/javascript/orangelight/availability.es6#L22 https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/blob/a1a88135b5331b30b087d97263c32da2fba208ac/app/javascript/orangelight/availability.es6#L330
@kevinreiss, @kelynch do we want to display this status again instead of 'Online'?
I approve of making this change where if I understand it the user will never see a request button for these items at any point no matter how slow the extra availability checks take.

@kevinreiss The current implementation **will initially show** the Request button for a few seconds (4-5 seconds) like it does for Reserves and then, **after Alma comes back with CDL info we hide them**. This is not ideal.

We could try to implement this the other way around: Initially hide the Request button and only show if after the Alma slow API comes back. But this will be a more complicated and riskier change so I would vote to do that separately so that we can test it extensively...because if we mess that one up the Request button won't show up if there is an Alma error or bug in our code.

orangelight.title: Exporting Bookmarks as a CSV returns the wrong ID number

comments.body:
I can't reproduce this. I exported the csv while logged in and not logged in:
`ID,Title,Title (Original Script),Author,Author (Original Script),Format,Language,Published/Created,Date,Description,Series,Location,Call Number,Notes
9912140633506421,Cats,"","","",Book,English,New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons,1974,108 p. illus. (part col.) 33 cm.,Animal world series,Stacks,Oversize QL737.C23C36.1974q,""`

@escowles is there more info on this issue?

@christinach I think the issue is really with Excel. That was the default app for handling CSV files for me, and it treats the long numeric IDs as numbers. It renders as `9.91214E+15` and when I look at the cell, I see the off-by-one value. So maybe there is some weird floating-point rounding going on? I'm not sure what we can do, but I think it will be pretty common to open the CSV files in Excel. I checked and Google Spreadsheets handles them just fine.
I understand @escowles . I will see what we can do.

requests.title: Purge remaining covid language from end user email notification templates.

Remove: 

If you are an undergraduate requesting to pick up books from a Library location other than Firestone, please be sure that you have access to the building. Access can be requested through your academic department.

Remove: 
When picking up and/or dropping off your books

Please do so promptly | Please do so promptly | Remain only in the designated pick-up area | Remain only in the designated pick-up area
